parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several management strategies for uncropped field margins have been shown to effectively support bumblebees on European farmland.
[Statement 2]: Sowing uncropped margins with agricultural nectar and pollen mixes attracts significantly more foraging bumblebees than naturally regenerated, grassy or cropped margins.
[Statement 3]: Agricultural nectar and pollen mixes containing perennial leguminous flowering plants are particularly effective at attracting foraging bumblebees.
[Statement 4]: The value of agricultural nectar and pollen mixes degrades over time, requiring the mixes to be re-sown every few years.
[Statement 5]: Native wildflower seed mixes support a higher abundance and species richness of bumblebees compared to cropped edges.
[Statement 6]: Perennial leguminous herbs provide important forage sources for bumblebees, especially for long-tongued species.
[Statement 7]: Naturally regenerated uncropped margins can support more bumblebees than cropped margins.
[Statement 8]: The value of naturally regenerated margins for bumblebees is often based on thistle species that are considered pernicious weeds.
[Statement 9]: The benefits for bumblebees from naturally regenerated uncropped margins are not consistent from year to year.
[Statement 10]: Providing grass strips at field margins can enhance bumblebee abundance and diversity.
[Statement 11]: Grass margins that are 6 meters wide have shown positive effects for bumblebees.
[Statement 12]: Conservation headlands, which are unsprayed field margins within crops, do not attract more foraging bumblebees than conventional fields.
[Statement 13]: During spring, rough grassland areas in field margins attract nest-searching queen bumblebees at higher densities than other habitat types.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What are the most effective ways to manage uncropped field margins on European farmland to support bumblebees?

fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__How do different management approaches for uncropped arable field margins in Europe, such as sowing mixes versus natural regeneration, compare in their benefits for bumblebees?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Field margins sown with agricultural nectar and pollen mixes attract significantly more foraging bumblebees than naturally regenerated margins.
[Statement 2]: Sown field margins degrade in their value to bumblebees.
[Statement 3]: Sown field margins need re-sowing every few years.
[Statement 4]: Native wildflower seed mixes perform better than natural regeneration for bumblebees.
[Statement 5]: Margins sown with native wildflower seed mixes show a higher abundance of bumblebees compared to naturally regenerated margins.
[Statement 6]: Margins sown with native wildflower seed mixes show a higher species richness of bumblebees compared to naturally regenerated margins.
[Statement 7]: Natural regeneration provides some benefits for bumblebees.
[Statement 8]: More bumblebees forage on uncropped naturally regenerated margins than on cropped margins.
[Statement 9]: More bee species are found on uncropped naturally regenerated margins than on cropped margins.
[Statement 10]: The value of naturally regenerated margins is often based on thistle species, which are considered pernicious weeds requiring control.
[Statement 11]: The value of naturally regenerated margins for bumblebees was not consistent from year to year.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__How does the effectiveness of planting phacelia (Phacelia tanacetifolia) as a floral resource for wild bees vary by location?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Ten trials from Europe and North America have monitored wild bees foraging on phacelia (Phacelia tanacetifolia) planted on farmland.
[Statement 2]: Nine trials monitoring phacelia on farmland found substantial numbers of foraging wild bees, particularly bumblebees (Bombus spp.).
[Statement 3]: Six trials recorded bee species richness on phacelia ranging from 8 to 35 species.
[Statement 4]: One replicated trial showed that phacelia is not very attractive to wild bees in Greece.
[Statement 5]: The effectiveness of phacelia as a floral resource for wild bees shows significant geographic variation.
[Statement 6]: Studies found that wildflower strips sown with phacelia had higher species richness or diversity of butterflies and moths compared to other flower species.
[Statement 7]: Three replicated studies found that sowing phacelia had negative impacts or no effects on overall biodiversity.

[Statement 1]: Several evidence-based actions can support wild bee populations in urban areas and along infrastructure corridors.
[Statement 2]: Managing land under power lines as scrub habitat supports more bee species than equivalent areas of annually mown grassland.
[Statement 3]: Stopping herbicide use on pavements and road verges increases butterfly species richness and abundance.
[Statement 4]: Restored roadside prairies with restricted herbicide application have shown greater butterfly species richness compared to verges dominated by non-native vegetation.
[Statement 5]: Managing land under power lines for butterflies and moths through mechanical cutting increases species richness compared to unmanaged land.
[Statement 6]: The optimal timing for mechanical cutting of land under power lines is 2-4 years after scrub and trees are cleared.
[Statement 7]: Altering mowing regimes on greenspaces and road verges to reduce mowing frequency or stop mowing entirely increases butterfly and moth species richness and abundance.
[Statement 8]: Less frequently mown urban greenspaces have been shown to have higher butterfly and moth species richness and diversity.
[Statement 9]: Establishing green infrastructure in urban areas, such as green roofs, provides habitat for wildlife.
[Statement 10]: Green roofs have been found to have lower butterfly species richness than urban parks.
[Statement 11]: Restoring or maintaining species-rich grassland along road verges by sowing with native wildflowers and butterfly larval food plants increases both butterfly species richness and abundance.
[Statement 12]: Roadside prairies sown with more butterfly species' larval food plants have been found to have greater butterfly and burnet moth abundance.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What actions can be taken to support wild bee populations in urban areas and along infrastructure corridors like roads and power lines?
fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What are the documented outcomes and challenges of rearing bumblebees in captivity for reintroduction?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Captive rearing of bumblebee colonies has been attempted in 22 trials across 13 countries using various methods.
[Statement 2]: Methods for captive rearing of bumblebees include confining mated queens alone or with different groups.
[Statement 3]: Three trials on captive rearing specifically focused on declining North American bumblebee species.
[Statement 4]: Captive rearing of yellow-banded bumblebees (B. terricola) has had some success.
[Statement 5]: Captive rearing of red-belted bumblebees (B. rufocinctus) has had some success.
[Statement 6]: There has been consistent failure in rearing yellow bumblebees (B. fervidus) because their larvae die before reaching adulthood.
[Statement 7]: There has been consistent failure in rearing rusty-patched bumblebees because their larvae die before reaching adulthood.
[Statement 8]: There has been consistent failure in rearing American bumblebees (B. pensylvanicus) because their larvae die before reaching adulthood.
[Statement 9]: Seven replicated trials monitored laboratory-reared bumblebee colonies that were released into the wild.
[Statement 10]: Four trials tracked the released laboratory-reared colonies until new queen production or queen death.
[Statement 11]: Two UK trials involving released laboratory-reared colonies showed very low or zero queen production.
[Statement 12]: Two trials involving released laboratory-reared colonies achieved good numbers of new queens.
[Statement 13]: Variable outcomes were observed regarding social parasitism of released colonies by cuckoo bees.
[Statement 14]: Two trials reported high parasitism rates of 25-66% and 79% by cuckoo bees.
[Statement 15]: Five trials reported no social parasites in the released bumblebee colonies.
[Statement 16]: The quality of a bumblebee colony's diet significantly impacts its reproductive success.
[Statement 17]: Bumblebee colonies fed freshly frozen pollen produced larger and longer-surviving queens than colonies fed dried, frozen pollen.
[Statement 18]: Higher protein pollen types increased the production of worker offspring in bumblebee colonies.
[Statement 19]: Artificial light regimes of 8 hours of light and 16 hours of darkness reduced egg-laying time for bumblebee queens compared to constant darkness.
[Statement 20]: Hibernating bumblebee queens at 4-5°C for 45 days enhanced egg-laying and colony formation.
[Statement 21]: Hibernating bumblebee queens at 4-5°C for 45 days resulted in smaller colonies.
[Statement 22]: For good survival rates, bumblebee queens need to weigh over 0.6 g.
[Statement 23]: For good survival rates, bumblebee queens need to be hibernated for four months or less.
[Statement 24]: One four-year study found that B. terrestris queens gradually decreased in weight during artificial rearing.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__How does the effectiveness of managing hedges for bees in Scotland compare to managing land under power lines for bees in the USA?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Based on available evidence, managing land under power lines in the USA appears to be more effective for bees than managing hedges in Scotland.
[Statement 2]: One replicated trial in Maryland, USA found more bee species under power lines managed as scrub than in equivalent areas of annually mown grassland.
[Statement 3]: One replicated controlled trial showed that hedges managed under the Scottish Rural Stewardship scheme do not attract more nest-searching or foraging queen bumblebees in spring than conventionally managed hedgerows.
[Statement 4]: Power line management has demonstrated positive effects on bee diversity.
[Statement 5]: Hedge management in Scotland showed no significant benefit for bumblebee activity compared to conventional management practices.

[Statement 1]: The evidence on bee translocation and genetic augmentation is limited.
[Statement 2]: One trial in Brazil demonstrated that genetic diversity can be maintained in small isolated populations of stingless bees (Melipona scutellaris).
[Statement 3]: The genetic diversity in small isolated populations of stingless bees (Melipona scutellaris) can be maintained by regularly introducing inseminated queens.
[Statement 4]: A replicated trial in India showed that translocating carpenter bees (Xylocopa fenestrata) in immature stages can establish a population at a new site.
[Statement 5]: When adult carpenter bees are translocated, only a very small proportion remain at the new site.
[Statement 6]: No evidence was found for the effects of ensuring genetic variation to increase translocation success in bees.
[Statement 7]: The effects of ensuring genetic variation to increase translocation success have been studied in taxa other than bees.
[Statement 8]: Systematic searches found no studies that directly evaluated the effects of introducing mated females to increase genetic diversity in butterflies and moths.
[Statement 9]: There is a significant gap in the evidence base for genetic augmentation across pollinator groups.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What is the extent of evidence on the success of translocating bees or augmenting small populations to improve genetic diversity?
fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What is the evidence for the effectiveness of different sown floral mixes on agricultural land for wild bees?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Evidence from European studies shows that sown floral mixes on agricultural land can significantly enhance wild bee populations, particularly bumblebees.
[Statement 2]: Agricultural nectar and pollen mixes containing perennial leguminous plants attract significantly more foraging bumblebees than naturally regenerated, grassy or cropped field margins.
[Statement 3]: Agricultural nectar and pollen mixes degrade in their value over time.
[Statement 4]: Agricultural nectar and pollen mixes need to be re-sown every few years.
[Statement 5]: Native wildflower mixes support a higher abundance and species richness of foraging bumblebees compared to cropped edges, grassy margins or naturally regenerated areas.
[Statement 6]: Perennial leguminous herbs are particularly important forage sources for long-tongued bumblebee species.
[Statement 7]: Planting dedicated floral resources, including phacelia, has been shown to result in substantial foraging by wild bees.
[Statement 8]: Trials have recorded between 8 and 35 bee species visiting planted patches of floral resources.
[Statement 9]: Agricultural forage plant mixtures that include legumes attract greater numbers of bumblebees than perennial wildflower mixes in the first year after establishment.
[Statement 10]: Evidence indicates that both agricultural mixes and native wildflower mixes are effective for supporting wild bees.
[Statement 11]: Agricultural mixes show a stronger initial attraction for wild bees than other mixes.
[Statement 12]: Agricultural mixes require more frequent re-sowing to maintain their effectiveness.

[Statement 1]: Evidence shows that creating patches of bare ground is effective for ground-nesting bees.
[Statement 2]: A replicated controlled trial in Germany and four small trials demonstrated that artificially exposed areas of bare soil can be successfully colonised by ground-nesting solitary bees and wasps.
[Statement 3]: The colonisation of artificially exposed bare soil by ground-nesting bees and wasps can occur within the first or second year.
[Statement 4]: No evidence exists for the effect of creating bare ground areas on bee populations at larger scales.
[Statement 5]: For ground-nesting bee habitat management, reduced tillage shows mixed results.
[Statement 6]: One replicated trial on squash farms in the USA found no difference in bee abundance between tilled and untilled farms.
[Statement 7]: Another replicated trial on squash farms in the USA found three times more squash bees on no-till farms compared to conventional farms.
[Statement 8]: Additional management for ground-nesting bees includes excluding ants from solitary bee nesting sites.
[Statement 9]: A replicated controlled trial showed that excluding ants from solitary bee nesting sites increased offspring production for the endemic Australian bee Exonuera nigrescens.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What evidence exists for creating or managing land to provide nesting sites for ground-nesting bees?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several actions have been studied to mitigate pesticide impacts on wild bees.
[Statement 2]: Reducing pesticide use generally has been investigated to mitigate impacts on wild bees.
[Statement 3]: Responsible pesticide use on squash farms did not affect numbers of foraging bees.
[Statement 4]: Restricting certain pesticides is a studied action to mitigate impacts on wild bees.
[Statement 5]: Avoiding late summer applications of the insecticide fenitrothion can prevent reductions in solitary bee species.
[Statement 6]: Providing buffer strips to reduce pesticide and nutrient run-off into field margins has been examined as a mitigation action.
[Statement 7]: Field margins managed with restrictions on fertilizer and pesticide use had a greater abundance of moths than conventionally managed margins.
[Statement 8]: Reducing the intensity of farmland meadow management, which includes limited agrochemical use, was studied as a mitigation action.
[Statement 9]: Meadows with a delayed first cutting and little agrochemical use had enhanced numbers and diversity of wild bees.
[Statement 10]: Some studies found no difference in bee diversity or abundance on meadows with reduced intensity of management.
[Statement 11]: A general reduction of fertilizers, pesticides or herbicides has been investigated.
[Statement 12]: A general reduction of fertilizers, pesticides, or herbicides was found to benefit some invertebrates, plants, or farmland birds.
[Statement 13]: A general reduction of fertilizers, pesticides, or herbicides was also found to have negative, mixed, minimal or no effects on various organisms.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What actions have been studied to mitigate the direct impacts of pesticides on wild bees?
fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__In the USA, what factors have been shown to affect the success of artificial nesting sites for solitary bees?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several factors have been shown to affect the success of artificial nesting sites for solitary bees in the USA.
[Statement 2]: Nest boxes for solitary bees must be placed within 150-600 meters of forage resources.
[Statement 3]: Reed stem and wooden grooved-board nest boxes produced more bees per nest than four other types of nest boxes.
[Statement 4]: Nest boxes with plastic-lined holes or plastic/paper tubes were much less productive due to parasitism or mold.
[Statement 5]: For the oil-collecting bee Centris analis in Brazil, cardboard straws placed in drilled wooden holes were more productive than grooved wooden boards stacked together.
[Statement 6]: A study on Osmia species in the USA showed that the number of occupied solitary bee nests can double over three years with repeated nest box provision at a given site.
[Statement 7]: Trials of drilled wooden nest boxes in California showed that introduced European earwigs and introduced European leafcutter bee species commonly occupied the boxes.
[Statement 8]: Introduced European earwigs and European leafcutter bee species sometimes occupied the wooden nest boxes in California more frequently than native bees.
[Statement 9]: Studies on artificial nesting sites for solitary bees recorded mortality rates ranging from 2% to 36% due to parasitism.
[Statement 10]: Studies on artificial nesting sites for solitary bees recorded an additional 20% mortality from other causes.

[Statement 1]: Agricultural forage plant mixes initially attract more bumblebees than native wildflower mixes.
[Statement 2]: Agricultural forage plant mixes are particularly attractive to bumblebees in the first year after sowing.
[Statement 3]: Agricultural forage plant mixes typically contain annual and perennial legumes.
[Statement 4]: Margins sown with agricultural legume plants tend to degrade in their value to bumblebees over time.
[Statement 5]: Margins sown with agricultural legume plants require re-sowing every few years.
[Statement 6]: Native wildflower mixes consistently support a higher abundance of foraging bumblebees compared to cropped field edges, grassy margins, or naturally regenerated margins.
[Statement 7]: Native wildflower mixes consistently support a higher species richness of foraging bumblebees compared to cropped field edges, grassy margins, or naturally regenerated margins.
[Statement 8]: Native wildflower mixes include perennial leguminous herbs.
[Statement 9]: Common long-tongued bumblebee species, such as Bombus pascuorum and B. hortorum, showed a strong preference for perennial wildflower seed mixes over annual forage plant mixes.
[Statement 10]: The perennial nature of wildflower mixes provides more sustained bumblebee foraging resources.
[Statement 11]: Wildflower mixes do not need the frequent re-sowing that is required by agricultural forage mixes.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__On UK farmland, how does sowing field margins with agricultural forage plants compare to native wildflower mixes for attracting bumblebees?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: A large replicated controlled trial showed that landscape-scale management is effective.
[Statement 2]: The average abundance of long-tongued bumblebees on field margins is positively correlated with the number of pollen and nectar agri-environment agreements in a 10 km grid square.
[Statement 3]: At the local patch scale, fourteen trials in Europe and North America recorded substantial numbers of wild bees foraging on perennial or annual sown flowering plants in agricultural environments.
[Statement 4]: Ten trials monitoring bees on phacelia patches found substantial numbers of foraging wild bees, particularly bumblebees.
[Statement 5]: Evidence for wider population responses to local patches of flowers is mixed.
[Statement 6]: One trial showed that planted lupine patches enhanced the reproductive success of blue orchard mason bees in apple orchards.
[Statement 7]: One Netherlands trial found no higher bee numbers or species richness in farmland 50-1,500 m from planted flower patches.
[Statement 8]: Two German trials found few solitary bees nesting on set-aside fields sown with phacelia or clover.
[Statement 9]: For field margin scale interventions, three UK trials on uncropped grassy field margins showed mixed effects.
[Statement 10]: One UK trial showed that 6-meter-wide margins enhanced wild bee abundance but not diversity at field boundaries.
[Statement 11]: One UK trial showed enhanced bumblebee abundance and diversity within field margins.
[Statement 12]: A third UK trial showed no differences in bee abundance or diversity on uncropped grassy field margins.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What is the evidence for the effectiveness of increasing floral resources for bees at a landscape scale versus a local patch scale on farmland?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Evidence from European studies shows that agri-environment schemes have mixed effectiveness for wild bees.
[Statement 2]: The effectiveness of agri-environment schemes for wild bees varies significantly between locations and scheme types.
[Statement 3]: Four replicated trials demonstrated enhanced diversity and/or abundance of foraging wild bees under various European agri-environment schemes.
[Statement 4]: Swiss Ecological Compensation Areas have been shown to enhance the diversity and/or abundance of foraging wild bees.
[Statement 5]: German organic arable farming has been shown to enhance the diversity and/or abundance of foraging wild bees.
[Statement 6]: Dutch botanical and meadow bird agreements have been shown to enhance the diversity and/or abundance of foraging wild bees.
[Statement 7]: The Scottish Rural Stewardship Scheme has been shown to enhance the diversity and/or abundance of foraging wild bees.
[Statement 8]: Four other replicated trials found no enhancement in bee numbers or species under different agri-environment schemes.
[Statement 9]: Dutch wet grassland meadow bird agreements were found not to enhance bee numbers or species.
[Statement 10]: Spanish steppe bird protection measures were found not to enhance bee numbers or species.
[Statement 11]: English 6m grass field margin strips were found not to enhance bee numbers or species in some trials.
[Statement 12]: Two UK landscape-scale trials found bumblebee populations were not enhanced on farmland under agri-environment schemes.
[Statement 13]: In the UK, field margins sown with wild flowers supported a higher abundance and species richness of foraging bumblebees compared to cropped or grassy margins.
[Statement 14]: Six-meter wide grassy field margins showed mixed results, with some UK trials enhancing bee abundance and diversity while others showed no difference.
[Statement 15]: The effectiveness of agri-environment schemes appears to depend on the design of the scheme.
[Statement 16]: Providing floral resources as part of a scheme generally shows more positive results for wild bees than the simple creation of grass margins.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__In Europe, what is the evidence for the effectiveness of agri-environment schemes for wild bees, and how does this vary between locations?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: For wild bees in European farmland, reducing management intensity in grassy habitats shows mixed but generally positive effects.
[Statement 2]: Four replicated trials in Europe found enhanced diversity and/or abundance of wild bees on meadows with reduced management intensity, specifically those with delayed first cutting and minimal agrochemical use.
[Statement 3]: Agri-environment schemes that include reduced management intensity have shown benefits for foraging wild bees in some European countries including Germany, Switzerland, the Netherlands, and Scotland.
[Statement 4]: Regarding specific management changes, reducing cutting frequency generally benefits pollinators including wild bees.
[Statement 5]: Meadows cut once per year support higher species richness and abundance of butterflies and other pollinators compared to meadows cut two or more times per year.
[Statement 6]: Delaying mowing or first grazing dates also provides benefits, with eight studies showing positive effects on invertebrates including increased insect visits to flowers.
[Statement 7]: The effects of completely ceasing management are more complex.
[Statement 8]: While cessation of mowing or grazing to allow early succession can benefit some insect species, this practice may not be optimal for all wild bee species as succession progresses.
[Statement 9]: Rotational approaches that create varied sward heights and maintain some management appear beneficial.
[Statement 10]: Studies show that mowing parts of sites at different times and leaving some areas uncut can enhance pollinator species richness and abundance.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__For farmland in Europe, what are the effects of reducing management intensity, such as mowing or grazing, in grassy habitats for wild bees?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Different low-intensity grassland management strategies show varying effectiveness for wild bees.
[Statement 2]: Restoring species-rich grassland has shown mixed results for wild bees.
[Statement 3]: Some trials found that restored species-rich grasslands had flower-visiting insect communities similar to those in ancient grasslands.
[Statement 4]: A replicated controlled trial showed species-rich grassland under agri-environment schemes attracted more nest-searching queen bumblebees compared to unmanaged grassland.
[Statement 5]: A replicated controlled trial showed species-rich grassland under agri-environment schemes attracted fewer foraging queen bumblebees compared to unmanaged grassland.
[Statement 6]: Reducing management intensity through a delayed first cut and reduced agrochemical use showed positive effects for wild bees.
[Statement 7]: Replicated trials found enhanced numbers and diversity of wild bees on extensively managed meadows compared to conventionally farmed meadows or silage fields.
[Statement 8]: Some trials found no difference in bee diversity or abundance between conventional meadows and meadows with reduced fertilizer use or cutting intensity.
[Statement 9]: Specific grazing reduction strategies showed limited benefits for wild bees.
[Statement 10]: Reducing grazing intensity by lowering stocking density had mixed effects on butterflies and moths.
[Statement 11]: Five of eight studies showed greater species richness of butterflies and moths at lower stocking densities.
[Statement 12]: Three studies showed similar species richness of butterflies and moths at both lower and higher stocking densities.
[Statement 13]: One replicated trial showed that reducing summer cattle grazing intensity increased the abundance of cavity-nesting bees and wasps.
[Statement 14]: One replicated trial showed that reducing summer cattle grazing intensity did not increase the species richness of cavity-nesting bees and wasps.
[Statement 15]: Agri-environment schemes showed mixed effectiveness for wild bees.
[Statement 16]: Four replicated trials demonstrated enhanced diversity and abundance of foraging wild bees under various European agri-environment schemes.
[Statement 17]: Four other trials found no enhancement in bee numbers or species richness under agri-environment schemes.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__How do different low-intensity grassland management strategies on farmland, such as restoring species-rich grassland or reducing grazing, compare in their effectiveness for wild bees?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Many solitary bee species from Europe, North and South America and Asia readily occupy artificial nest sites.
[Statement 2]: Artificial nest sites for solitary bees include cut hollow stems, tubes, and blocks of wood drilled with holes.
[Statement 3]: Reed stem and wooden grooved-board nest boxes have higher productivity than plastic-lined holes or plastic/paper tubes.
[Statement 4]: Plastic-lined holes or plastic/paper tubes used as artificial nests can experience increased parasitism and mould issues.
[Statement 5]: Cardboard straws placed in drilled wooden holes produce more nests than grooved wooden boards that are stacked together.
[Statement 6]: The placement of nest boxes for solitary bees is a critical factor.
[Statement 7]: Solitary bees have foraging ranges of 150 to 600 meters.
[Statement 8]: Nest boxes for solitary bees must be placed within 150 to 600 meters of forage resources.
[Statement 9]: Mortality rates for solitary bees in artificial nests vary significantly.
[Statement 10]: Brood cell attack in Indonesian plantations was recorded at 2%.
[Statement 11]: The overall mortality for carpenter bees in India was recorded at 56%.
[Statement 12]: Introduced species may competitively occupy nest boxes over native bees.
[Statement 13]: Soil-filled nest boxes designed for mining bees have proven to be unsuccessful.
[Statement 14]: Providing nest boxes repeatedly over multiple years can double the number of occupied nests.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What factors are known to influence the occupancy and productivity of artificial nest sites provided for solitary bees?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Limited evidence exists for landscape-scale effects of bee conservation interventions beyond immediate sites.
[Statement 2]: A large replicated controlled trial found that the average abundance of long-tongued bumblebees on field margins was positively correlated with the number of pollen and nectar agri-environment agreements in a 10 km grid square.
[Statement 3]: The positive correlation between bumblebee abundance and agri-environment agreements suggests landscape-scale benefits from multiple interventions.
[Statement 4]: For interventions targeting natural habitat restoration and connectivity, no evidence was found demonstrating effects on bee diversity or abundance in neighboring farms.
[Statement 5]: No evidence was found demonstrating effects on wild bee communities from connecting habitat patches.
[Statement 6]: Butterfly and moth studies show increased species richness and abundance with greater proportions of semi-natural habitat in landscapes.
[Statement 7]: Specific evidence for bees showing increased species richness and abundance with greater proportions of semi-natural habitat is lacking.
[Statement 8]: One study found more wild bee species and individuals in planted flower strips compared to unplanted strips.
[Statement 9]: The presence of more wild bees in planted flower strips represents immediate site effects rather than landscape-scale spillover.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What evidence exists for the landscape-scale effects of bee conservation interventions, beyond the immediate site of action?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several unintended negative consequences and limitations have been identified when providing artificial nest boxes for bees.
[Statement 2]: High rates of parasitism and mortality in artificial nest boxes for bees have been documented.
[Statement 3]: Mortality rates in artificial nest boxes for bees have ranged from 2-56% across different studies.
[Statement 4]: Parasitism rates reached 36% for the subtropical carpenter bee Xylocopa fenestrata in India.
[Statement 5]: Overall mortality reached 56% for the subtropical carpenter bee Xylocopa fenestrata.
[Statement 6]: Artificial nest boxes for bees can facilitate the spread and establishment of introduced species.
[Statement 7]: In California, USA, European earwigs Forficula auricularia and introduced European leafcutter bee species used artificial nest boxes more commonly than native bees.
[Statement 8]: The use of artificial nest boxes by introduced earwigs led to the development of exclusion methods specifically targeting the earwigs.
[Statement 9]: Certain artificial nest box designs for bees have proven to be problematic.
[Statement 10]: Artificial nest boxes with plastic-lined holes, or plastic or paper tubes, were much less productive due to parasitism or mould.
[Statement 11]: Some artificial nest box types, particularly surface wooden boxes marketed for wildlife gardening, show very low uptake rates.
[Statement 12]: Recent UK trials of surface wooden boxes for bees showed very low uptake rates of 0-2.5%, questioning the boxes' effectiveness.
[Statement 13]: For bumblebees, wooden surface or above ground boxes are not the most effective design.
[Statement 14]: Wooden surface or above ground boxes for bumblebees show consistently low occupancy rates.
[Statement 15]: In a small UK trial, soil-filled nest boxes for the mining bee Andrena flavipes were not occupied at all.
[Statement 16]: The lack of occupation in a small trial suggests that using soil-filled nest boxes for the mining bee Andrena flavipes is an ineffective approach.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What unintended negative consequences or limitations have been identified when providing artificial nest boxes for bees?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: The most effective artificial nest box design for bumblebees is an underground box entirely buried 5-10 cm below ground level with a 30-80 cm long entrance pipe.
[Statement 2]: The underground nest box design for bumblebees achieved occupancy rates between 6% and 58% in trials.
[Statement 3]: The underground nest box design for bumblebees significantly outperforms wooden surface or above-ground nest boxes.
[Statement 4]: Wooden surface or above-ground nest boxes for bumblebees showed very low occupancy rates of 0-1.5% in recent UK trials.
[Statement 5]: Underground bumblebee nest boxes made from various materials including tin, wood, or terracotta were tested across the USA, Canada, and the UK.
[Statement 6]: All studies of underground bumblebee nest boxes demonstrated superior performance compared to above-ground alternatives.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What is the most effective design for an artificial nest box intended for bumblebees?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Studies have shown mixed effects of agri-environment schemes on wild bees in European farmland.
[Statement 2]: Four replicated trials across Europe demonstrated enhanced diversity and/or abundance of foraging wild bees under agri-environment schemes compared to conventionally managed fields.
[Statement 3]: The trials demonstrating enhanced wild bee diversity and/or abundance included the Swiss Ecological Compensation Areas, German organic arable farming, Dutch botanical and meadow bird agreements, and the Scottish Rural Stewardship Scheme.
[Statement 4]: Four other replicated trials found that agri-environment schemes did not enhance bee numbers or species richness.
[Statement 5]: The trials that found agri-environment schemes did not enhance bee numbers or species richness included meadow bird agreements in Dutch wet grasslands.
[Statement 6]: The trials that found agri-environment schemes did not enhance bee numbers or species richness included steppe bird protection measures in Spain.
[Statement 7]: The trials that found agri-environment schemes did not enhance bee numbers or species richness included grass field margin strips in England.
[Statement 8]: At the landscape scale, two UK replicated trials found that bumblebee populations were not enhanced on farmland managed under agri-environment schemes.
[Statement 9]: One UK study comparing the reproductive success of buff-tailed bumblebee colonies found that bumblebee populations were not enhanced on farmland managed under agri-environment schemes.
[Statement 10]: Another UK study examining queen bumblebee numbers in spring found that bumblebee populations were not enhanced on farmland managed under agri-environment schemes.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What are the documented effects on wild bees of introducing agri-environment schemes on European farmland?
fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__How does sowing agricultural forage plants on field margins compare to sowing native wildflower mixes in terms of benefits for bumblebees?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Agricultural forage plant mixes, particularly those containing perennial leguminous flowering plants, attract significantly more foraging bumblebees than naturally regenerated, grassy, or cropped field margins.
[Statement 2]: Agricultural forage plant mixes attracted greater numbers of bumblebees than perennial wildflower mixes, at least in the first year.
[Statement 3]: Agricultural legume margins degrade in their value to bumblebees over time and require re-sowing every few years.
[Statement 4]: Native wildflower mixes support a higher abundance and species richness of foraging bumblebees compared to cropped field edges, grassy margins, or naturally regenerated margins.
[Statement 5]: Perennial leguminous herbs in wildflower seed mixtures are particularly important forage sources for long-tongued bumblebee species.
[Statement 6]: Common long-tongued bumblebee species (Bombus pascuorum and B. hortorum) strongly preferred plots of perennial wildflower seed mix over annual forage plants.

[Statement 1]: Several factors affect the success of captive-rearing and reintroducing bumblebee colonies.
[Statement 2]: Diet composition significantly influences the reproductive success of bumblebee colonies.
[Statement 3]: Bumblebee colonies fed on freshly frozen pollen produced larger queens that survived better and produced larger colonies than colonies fed on dried, frozen pollen.
[Statement 4]: B. terrestris workers can produce more offspring when fed pollen with higher protein content.
[Statement 5]: Social parasitism by cuckoo bees is a critical factor in the success of released bumblebee colonies.
[Statement 6]: Released bumblebee colonies have shown highly variable parasitism rates, ranging from 25-79%.
[Statement 7]: Social parasitism of bumblebee colonies could be reduced by placing the colonies in landscapes with intermediate, rather than very high, nectar and pollen availability.
[Statement 8]: Social parasitism of bumblebee colonies could be reduced by releasing the colonies later rather than earlier in the season.
[Statement 9]: Supplementary feeding of bumblebee colonies has shown mixed results.
[Statement 10]: One trial found supplementary feeding improved the reproductive success of captive-reared colonies but did not reduce the parasite load.
[Statement 11]: A separate trial found no increase in colony productivity resulted from supplementary feeding.
[Statement 12]: Captive rearing methods affect the success of bumblebee colony reintroduction.
[Statement 13]: One trial found that bumblebee queens gradually decreased in weight over four years of artificial rearing.
[Statement 14]: Laboratory rearing has shown variable success for different North American bumblebee species.
[Statement 15]: Some bumblebee species, like B. fervidus, lay eggs during laboratory rearing but experience larval mortality before the larvae reach adulthood.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What factors, such as diet and social parasitism, have been shown to affect the success of captive-rearing and reintroducing bumblebee colonies?
